aws::graph::propositions: # Amazon Prime Velocity Autonomous Delivery Network Announcement
Amazon unveiled "Prime Velocity," an autonomous delivery network.
Prime Velocity will transform how goods move from warehouses to customers' doorsteps.
Prime Velocity integrates self-driving delivery vehicles.
Prime Velocity integrates aerial drone networks.
Prime Velocity integrates fully robotic fulfillment centers.
Amazon calls Prime Velocity "the world's first end-to-end autonomous logistics ecosystem."
Prime Velocity launches initially in 15 major cities across North America.
Prime Velocity launches initially in 15 major cities across Europe.
Prime Velocity launches initially in 15 major cities across Asia.
Amazon plans to expand Prime Velocity to 100 metropolitan areas by 2026.
Nexus Hubs are Amazon's new massive automated fulfillment centers.
Nexus Hubs use robotic systems to process orders without human intervention.
Nexus Hubs use robotic systems to package orders without human intervention.
Nexus Hubs use robotic systems to dispatch orders without human intervention.
Nexus Hubs operate 24 hours a day.
Nexus Hubs operate with 99.9% accuracy.
Marcus Rodriguez is Amazon's Vice President of Autonomous Operations.
Marcus Rodriguez explained "We're witnessing the dawn of truly intelligent logistics."
Amazon's AI systems can predict what customers will order before customers know it themselves.
Amazon's AI systems pre-position inventory.
Amazon's AI systems optimize delivery routes in real-time.
Amazon's AI systems achieve delivery times that seemed impossible five years ago.

metadata.header_path: /Amazon Launches Autonomous Delivery Network Across Three Continents/
/Amazon Launches Autonomous Delivery Network Across Three Continents/

text:
## News Report

Amazon today unveiled "Prime Velocity," an ambitious autonomous delivery network that will fundamentally transform how goods move from warehouses to customers' doorsteps. The system integrates self-driving delivery vehicles, aerial drone networks, and fully robotic fulfillment centers to create what the company calls "the world's first end-to-end autonomous logistics ecosystem."

The network launches initially in 15 major cities across North America, Europe, and Asia, with plans to expand to 100 metropolitan areas by 2026. At the heart of the system are Amazon's new "Nexus Hubs" â€“ massive automated fulfillment centers where robotic systems can process, package, and dispatch orders without human intervention, operating 24 hours a day with 99.9% accuracy.

"We're witnessing the dawn of truly intelligent logistics," explained Marcus Rodriguez, Amazon's Vice President of Autonomous Operations. "Our AI systems can predict what customers will order before they know it themselves, pre-positioning inventory and optimizing delivery routes in real-time to achieve delivery times that seemed impossible just five years ago."
